This is a hands-on introduction to `Pandas`, probably the most important `Python` library for handling data frames.
 
 
 <br>
 
# Create a new table (data-frame)


First of all, obviously, we need to import the `Pandas` library.

```python
import pandas as pd
```



We can create a new table (data-frame) using `Pandas` as follows:


```python
AlumnoID = pd.Series(['A1', 'A2', 'A3', 'A4', 'A5', 'A6', 'A7', 'A8', 'A9', 'A10','A11','A12', 'A13'])
Nombre = pd.Series(['Orlando', 'Keith', 'Donna', 'Janet', 'Fabio', 'Juan', 'Lucia', 'Pedro', 'Sergio', 'Grecia', 'Ismael', 'Luis', 'Pedro'])
Pais = pd.Series(['Australia', 'India', 'Germany', 'United States', 'España', 'España', 'España', 'Italia', 'United States', 'Peru','España','España','Argentina'])
Ciudad = pd.Series(['','','Berlin','California','Madrid', 'Sevilla', '', 'Roma', 'New York', 'Lima', 'Madrid', 'Murcia', 'Buenos Aires'])
Email = pd.Series(['','keith0@adventure-works.com','donna0@adventure-works.com','janet1@adventure-works.com','fabio10@gmail.com', '', 'LuciaPerez@hotmail.com', 'Pedro99@gmail.com', 'sergio_as@gmail.com', 'Grecia89@gmail.com', 'Isma98@gmail.com', 'Luismiguel123@gmail.com', 'Pedro120@gmail.com'])
Telefono = pd.Series(['917755028', '', '915547890', '', '', '915869028', '', '910007890', '', '', '912234543', '', ''])
```


```python
Alumnos = pd.DataFrame({'AlumnoID': AlumnoID ,  'Nombre': Nombre, 'Pais':Pais , 
                         'Ciudad':Ciudad, 'Email':Email, 'Telefono':Telefono})
```

```python
Alumnos
```

Now we are going to create two additional tables:


```python
ProfesorID = pd.Series(['P1', 'P2', 'P3', 'P4', 'P5', 'P6', 'P7'])
Nombre = pd.Series(['Juan', 'Sonia', 'Lucia', 'Marcos', 'Carlos', 'Daniel', 'Garazi'])
Estudios =  pd.Series(['Matemáticas', 'Física', 'Lengua', 'Biología', 'Educación Física', 'Geografía', 'Inglés'])
Email = pd.Series(['JuanPerez@colegio.es','SoniDiaz@colegio.es','LuciaPerez@colegio.es','MarcosSanz@colegio.es','CarlosFernandez@colegio.es', 'DanielOrtiz@colegio.es', 'GaraziGarcia@colegio.es'])
```


```python
Profesores = pd.DataFrame({'ProfesorID': ProfesorID, 'Nombre': Nombre, 'Estudios':Estudios , 'Email':Email})
```

```python
ExamenId = pd.Series(['E1', 'E2', 'E3', 'E4', 'E5'])
Nota = pd.Series([6.7, 8, 4.25, 6.5, 7])
Asignatura = pd.Series(['Matemáticas', 'Física', 'Matemáticas', 'Inglés', 'Lengua'])
AlumnoID = pd.Series(['A2','A4','A1','A7', 'A9'])
ProfesorID = pd.Series(['P1', 'P2', 'P1', 'P7', 'P3'])
```


```python
Examenes = pd.DataFrame({'ExamenId': ExamenId, 'Nota': Nota, 'Asignatura':Asignatura , 
                         'AlumnoID':AlumnoID, 'ProfesorID':ProfesorID})
```

# Number of rows and columns

We can get the number of rows and columns of a data-frame:


```ruby
House_Price_Data.shape
```




    (1905, 29)


<br>

The number of rows:

```ruby
House_Price_Data.shape[0]
```




    1905

<br>

Another way to get the number of rows:

```ruby
len(House_Price_Data)
```




    1905
    

<br>

The number of columns:

```ruby
House_Price_Data.shape[1]
```




    29

# Rename columns from a data-frame

For one thing, we can create a new data frame the same as the original, but with different names for some of its columns:


On the other hand, we can rename specific columns of a data-frame without the need to create a new additional data-frame setting the  `inplace` parameter  to `True`:

```python
House_Price_Data.rename(columns={'neighborhood_recode' : 'neighborhood'}, inplace=True)
```

# Group by

We can group the rows of the data frame by the values in one column and then compute within each group a statistic from some of the other columns:

```python
House_Price_Data.groupby('quality_recode').sum()
```

We create two new data-frames that will have the same column names, to show how `concat( , index=0)` works in this case:


```python
X1 = pd.Series([ 2 , 4 , 3, 35, 23 ])
X2 = pd.Series([10, 12, 3, 3, -13])
X3 = pd.Series([22, 33, 1, 5, -3])
X4 = pd.Series([52, 2, 23, 6, -5])
X5 = pd.Series([ 22 , 34 , 13, 35, 23 ])
X6 = pd.Series([10, 12, 32, 30, -13])
X7 = pd.Series([22, 33, 1, 56, -13])
X8 = pd.Series([5, 12, 2, 66, -5])

df1 = pd.DataFrame( {"X1": X1 , "X2": X2 , "X3": X3 , "X4": X4} ) 

df2 = pd.DataFrame( {"X1": X5 , "X2": X6 , "X3": X7 , "X4": X8} )
```

# Join data-frames using `merge`


## Inner Join 

The inner join operation applied to two data frames $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_1\hspace{0.01cm}$ and $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_2\hspace{0.01cm}$ produces another data frame consisting of the union of the rows of $DF_1$ and $DF_2$ that share the same value in the link column (share linking value).



```python
pd.merge(Examenes, Alumnos, on='AlumnoID', how='inner')  # equivalent to inner join
```

## Outer Join

 
The outer join operation applied to two data frames $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_1\hspace{0.01cm}$ and $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_2\hspace{0.01cm}$ produces the same data frame of inner join, but adding the rows from $DF_1$ that don't share linking value with any row from $DF_2$, and the rows from $DF_2$ that don't share linking value with any row form $DF_1$.

## Right Join

The right join operation applied to two data frames $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_1\hspace{0.01cm}$ and $\hspace{0.01cm}DF_2\hspace{0.01cm}$ produces another data frame consisting of the rows of $DF_1$ and $DF_2$ that share link value, and the rest rows of $DF_2$.



```python
pd.merge(Examenes, Alumnos, on='AlumnoID', how='right')  # equivalent to right join
```
